title: Making standards work for you
body:
In our final module, we examine where local authorities can find the right support to help them publish good quality, consistent open data. In this module we examine how resources like LG Inform Plus can save you time and money in publishing your data.

Below you can learn about how to find relevant schemas, the best way to put a licence on your dataset, using persistent URIs and some examples of where authorities have benefitted most from following these practices.

title: Navigating LG Inform Plus
body:
LG Inform Plus is a collection of support tools and guidance that can help any local government quickly make sense of open data. Maintained by LGA, Inform Plus provides the standards that allow your local open data to be combined with other authorities to create regional and national insights. Every authority has to meet the demands of the transparency agenda and publish open data. LG Inform Plus takes the pain out of this process and saves you staff time and money

In the following sections, we will guide you through the key resources available via LG Inform Plus and show you how to apply these to support your own open data publishing.

title: Finding the right schema
body: Consistent publication brings a range of benefits for local authorities.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Core open data schemas
_items.body:
LGA keeps a definitive set of schemas for 10 of the most popular open datasets published by local authorities. If you are publishing data in one of these categories, we strongly recommend following the relevant schema below:
Contracts
Land and Buildings
Organisation Structure
Parking
Senior Employees
Senior Employee Count
Spend
Planning Applications
Premises Licences
Public Toilets

If the dataset you are publishing isnt covered above, scroll right to find out about community schemas.

_items.title: Community open data schemas
_items.body:
If the dataset you are publishing is not covered by one of the core schemas published by LGA, you may be able to find a common schema from othder local authorities in the community. The LGA schema directory keeps track of over 640 schemas from local authorities across the UK. Simply search the directory for the type of data you plan to publish and it will show you the common schemas that match.
Take me to the LGA community schema directory
If the dataset you are publishing isn't covered by any of those in the community, it may be nescessary to create your own schema. However there are still some guidelines that can help you create a good one. Scroll right to find these guidelines.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body: You should only create a new schema if there is no existing one in the LGA directory that matches your dataset. You should

title: Are you ready to find examples of good publication?

body: Can you recall these four things about the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities?

title: Benefits of consistent publishing
body: Which of the following is a benefit of publishing in a consistent way?

_items.text: Easier to share data between departments

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Publishing open data cin a consistent format makes it simple for people to get the data they need without contacting different departments.

_incorrect.notFinal:
h5>Are you sure about that?

title: Legal considerations
body: There are three legal considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...

_items.text: not to break the licensing law.
to publish any type of data.
to protect sensitive information such as personal data.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. Protect sensitive information like personal data, preserve the rights of data owners and promote correct use of the data.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Are you sure about that?

title: Technical considerations
body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...

_items.text: What format the open data is published in.
Whether it can it be used on a computer.
Whether it takes up much bandwidth.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_incorrect.notFinal:

title: How can I take the stress out of open data publication?
displayTitle: How can I take the stress out of open data publication?
body:
In our first module we explored the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities. In this module we look at one of the biggest barriers to realising those benefits - inconsistent publishing approaches. Many authorities are unaware of the support available to them in publishing consistent, usable data.

Below you can learn about the benefits of following consistent publishing approaches, access the best resources to support you and understand a simple assessment checklist that can save hours of staff time in every release.
